text: common mistakes English lesson 8 topic
used to well that wasn't too good I used
to be better with two small children I
just don't have the time to practice
anymore is there something you used to
do something you really enjoyed why did
you stop maybe by the end of this lesson
you'll be able to tell me in this lesson
we'll look at three common expressions
used to be used to and get used to they
can easily cause confusion because there
are similarities in form and in meaning
[Music]
this is a lesson in two parts in part 1
we'll cover use two and be used to let's
first look at used to this structure
expresses that something was true or
common in the past but isn't now or it
expresses that something happened often
in the past but doesn't happen now so we
can use this structure to describe past
States and situations or past events and
actions what's important to understand
is that this structure helps us create a
contrast between the past and the
present let's look at two examples I
used to be better at the piano this
means I was better in the past now I'm
not that good in the second example I
used to play more often this means in
the past I played more often I don't
play much anymore do you see the
contrast this idea of contrasting the
past in the present can be expressed
more than one way I used to play a lot
means the same as I do not play a lot
I do not play a lot anymore I no longer
play a lot so used to means not now not
anymore no longer the difference is that
this expression used to is a past tense
structure let's look more closely at the
structure or form in affirmative and
negative statements the first is
affirmative I used to practice regularly
we have used two plus the base verb the
second statement is negative I didn't
use to complain about not having time to
practice didn't plus used to plus the
base verb note that didn't already
signals the past so used to is written
without that IDI ending now let's look
at the structure of questions did you
use to play a lot
the structure is did + subject + used to
+ the base verb it's also fairly common
to ask negative questions didn't you use
to take lessons we asked this negative
question because we think we're right
but we need somebody to confirm our
information and then of course we could
ask a question with a question word or
phrase example how often did you use to
play question word + did + subject +
used to + base verb
please note 2 different pronunciations
of the structure when it's followed by a
consonant sound we do not pronounce used
to with a full vowel sound - becomes - I
used to practice regularly I didn't use
to complain so much
both the affirmative and the negative
form have the same pronunciation Houston
in contrast we keep the full vowel sound
when the structure is followed by a
vowel sound or when it stands at the end
of a statement for example I used to
entertain my grandmother with my music
do you play
I used to
exercise 1
watch the video clip and then answer the
question example listen to Jennifer talk
about playing the piano when I was
younger I used to practice quite often
which statement is true about Jennifer a
she practices more now than she did in
the past
B she practiced more in the past than
she does now see she has always
practiced a lot answer B
one listen to Gina talk about her work
what do you do I am retired
what kind of work did you used to do I
used to be a social worker for troubled
families which statement is true about
Gina a she helps troubled families be
she doesn't want to retire see she was a
social worker but no longer is answer
see
to listen to Carol talk about sports do
you play sport
I used to which statement about Carol is
true a she doesn't play sports anymore B
she never played sports see she can't
play sports answer a
three listen to Carol talk about tennis
how often did you play tennis I used to
play tennis almost every day which
statement about Carroll is true a she
continues to play tennis as often as she
can be there was a time in the past when
she played nearly every day see she's
better now at tennis than she ever was
in the past answer be watch and listen
try to answer these two questions
one is it easy for Jennifer to play this
fast piece of music too is she
comfortable playing the piano on camera
[Music]
my fingers just aren't used to moving
that fast I'm also not used to
performing on camera but I'm a little
nervous the answers it's not easy for
Jennifer to play this fast piece of
music she isn't comfortable playing the
piano on camera this second structure be
used to expresses that something is
familiar comfortable or normal for
someone it's not limited to the past in
fact very often we use it to describe
what we're accustomed to in the present
let's look at two examples my fingers
aren't used to moving that fast
this means it's not easy for my fingers
to move that fast it's not a normal
activity I'm not used to performing on
camera means I'm not comfortable
performing on camera now let's look at
form we have two examples I'm used to my
electronic keyboard I'm not used to
performing on camera in both statements
the verb of B agrees with the subject
the first statement is affirmative
the second is negative this structure is
followed by an object it answers the
question what the object can be a noun
or pronoun or a gerund the ing form of
the verb
